Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(n \geq 1\).

Let \(\mathscr{B}_1\) and \(\mathscr{B}_2\) be two basis of \(E\). We say that \(\mathscr{B}_1\) and \(\mathscr{B}_2\) have {{c1::the same orientation}} if {{c1::the transition matrix \(P\) from \(\mathscr{B}_1\) to \(\mathscr{B}_2\)}} has {{c1::positive determinant \(\det(A) > 0\)}}. 

Otherwise, we say that \(\mathscr{B}_1\) and \(\mathscr{B}_2\) have {{c1::opposite orientations}}.

We can define a relation \(\sim\) on the set of basis of \(E\) as follows: we say \(\mathscr{B}_1 \sim \mathscr{B}_2\) if \(\mathscr{B}_1\) and \(\mathscr{B}_2 \) have {{c1::the same orientation}}.

The relation \(\sim\) is an equivalence relation on the set of all basis of \(E\). In addition, there are exactly two equivalence classes for the relation \(\sim\).
The set of equivalence classes of \(\sim\) is the set of {{c1::orientations of \(E\)}}. {{c1::An orientation of \(E\)}} is the choice of such an equivalence class.
Choosing an orientation is equivalent to {{c1::choosing a reference basis}}.

Given an orientation of \(E\) and given a basis \(\mathscr{B}\) belonging to this orientation, we say {{c1::a basis \(\mathscr{B}'\) is direct}} if {{c2::\(\mathscr{B}  \sim \mathscr{B}'\)}}. Otherwise, we say \(\mathscr{B}' \) is {{c1::undirect}}.

Then, any vector \(u \in E\) writes in a unique way as \[u = \sum_{i=1}^n u_ie_i\] where \(u_i = f_i(u)\), and we have \[q(u) = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i(f_i(u))^2 = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i(u_i)^2.\]

This implies \(\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(q) = \text{diag}(\alpha_1,...,\alpha_n)\) and the conclusion follows from Lemma 2.5.

Let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\) be a quadratic form on \(E\). There exists a basis \((f_1,...,f_n)\) of \(E^\star\) and \(\alpha_1,...,\alpha_n \in \mathbb{K}\) such that for any \(u \in E\), {{c1::\[q(u)=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\alpha_j \cdot (f_j(u))^2\]}} Moreover, the rank of \(q\) is {{c1::\(\text{Card}(\{1 \leq j \leq n\ : \alpha_j \neq 0\})\)}}.
Any symmetric matrix is {{c1::congruent to a diagonal matrix}}.

If \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\) is {{c2::non-degenerate}} and if \(\mathscr{B} = (e_1,..., e_n)\) is {{c2::an orthogonal basis with \(q(e_i ) = \pm 1\)}}, we say \(\mathscr{B}\) is {{c1::an orthonormal basis for \(q\)}}.

We now assume \(E\) is a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(n < +\infty\). 

Let \(q\) be a quadratic form on \(E\). There exist a couple \((p, s)\) of non-negative integers such that {{c1::\(p + s = \text{rank}(q) \leq n\)}} and for any orthogonal basis \(\mathscr{B} = (e_1 ,..., e_n)\) for \(q\), we have {{c1::\[ \begin{cases} p = \text{Card}(\{1\leq i \leq n : q(e_i)>0\}) \\ s =  \text{Card}(\{1\leq i \leq n : q(e_i)<0\})\end{cases}\]}}
Let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). The couple of integers \((p, s)\) given by the Sylverer law of inertia is called the {{c1::signature of the quadratic form \(q\)}}.

Let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\) be a quadratic form of signature \((p, s)\). Then

1. {{c2::\(q\) is non-degenerate}} if and only if {{c1::\(p + s = n\)}},

2. {{c1:: \(q\) is positive}} if and only if {{c2::\(s = 0\)}},

3. {{c2::\(q\) is positive definite}} if and only if {{c1::\((p, s) = (n,0)\)}}.

We let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(n < +\infty\).

Two quadratic forms on \(E\) are equivalent if and ony if {{c1::they have the same signature}}.

We let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{C}\)-vector space of dimension \(n < +\infty\).

Two quadratic forms on \(E\) are equivalent if and ony if {{c1::they have the same rank}}.

On the other hand, in the canonical basis \(\mathscr{B}\) of \(\mathbb{R}^2\), the matrix of q is \[\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(q) = \begin{pmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.\]}}

Any vector \(u \in \ker(q)\) is isotropic, but the converse is false. 

Indeed, again in the above (2.8.1.) example, we have {{c1::\(\ker(q) = \{0\}\) by Proposition 1.15, but \(u = (1,1) \neq 0\) is isotropic.}}
If any vector is isotropic for \(q\), then {{c1::\(q \equiv 0\)}}.

A subset \(C\) of a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space \(E\) is a cone if {{c1::for any \(\lambda \geq 0\) and any \(u \in C\), we have \(\lambda u \in C\), i.e. \(\lambda C \subset C\)}}.

Remark that a cone always {{c1::contains the vector \(0\)}}.

We denote by \(C(q)\) {{c1::the set of isotropic vector of \(q\): \[C(q) := \{u \in E : q(u) = 0\}\]}}

The set \(C(q)\) is called {{c1::the isotropic cone of \(q\)}}.
If \(E\) is {{c1::a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space}} and \(q \in Q(E)\), the set \(C(q)\) is {{c1::a cone}}.

Assume \(E\) is a \(\mathbb{C}\)-vector space of dimension \(n \geq 2\) and let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). There exist {{c1::a non-zero isotropic vector \(u \in E\)}}. In other words, {{c1::\(C(q) \neq \{0\}.\)}}

A vector subspace \(F \subset E\) is isotropic if {{c1::\(C(q) \cap F \neq \{0\}\)}}, i.e. if {{c1::\(q|_F\) admits an isotropic vector}}. Otherwise, we say \(F\) is anisotropic. 

We say {{c1::\(F\) is totally isotropic}} if {{c2::\(F \subset F^\perp\)}}.

The space \(E\) itself is anisotropic if and only if {{c1::\(q\) is definite}}. Indeed, \(E\) is anisotropic if and only if {{c2::\(C(q) = \{0\}\), i.e. \(q(u) \neq 0\) for all \(u \in E âˆ’ \{0\}\)}}.
More generally, a subspace \(F\) is anisotropic if and only if {{c2::\(q|_F\) is definite}}. In particular, if \(F\) is anisotropic, then {{c1::\(E = F\oplus F^\perp\)}}, by Corollary 2.4.
A vector subspace \(F\) is totally isotropic if and only if {{c1::\(\text{rad}(F) = F\)}}, i.e. if {{c2::\(q\) vanishes identically on \(F\)}}.
If \(u \in E âˆ’ \{0\}\) and \(F = \text{Span}(u)\), then {{c1::u is isotropic}} iff {{c2::\(F\) is isotropic iff \(F\) is totally isotropic}}.
If {{c1::\(F\) is isotropic}}, then \(\text{rad}(F)\) is {{c2::totally isotropic}}.
If \(q\) is non-degenerate and if \(F\) is a totally isotropic subspace of \(E\), we have {{c1::\[2\dim F \leq \dim E\]}}
The index of the quadratic form \(q\), denoted by \(\nu(q)\), is {{c1::the maximal dimension of a totally isotropic subspace of \(E\)}}.

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-plane, i.e. a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(2\).

\((E,q)\) is a hyperbolic plane if there are vectors \(e_1, e_2 \in E âˆ’ \{0\}\) such that {{c1::\[q(e_1) = q(e_2) = 0 \text{ and } \varphi(e_1, e_2) = 1\]}}
The collection \((e_1 , e_2)\) is called a hyperbolic basis of \(E\) for \(q\) and we say \(q\) is a hyperbolic quadratic form.

Note that \(\mathscr{B} = (e_1 , e_2)\) is a actual basis of \(E\). Indeed, if \(e_1\) and \(e_2\) are not linearly independent, {{c1::there exis \(\lambda \in \mathbb{R} âˆ’ \{0\}\) such that \(e_2 = \lambda e_1\) and \(\varphi(e_1 , e_2) = \varphi(e_1, \lambda e_1) = \lambda q(e_1) = 0\)}}.

More generally, if \((u_1,u_2) \in E^2\) satisfies \[q(u_1) = q(u_2) = 0 \text{ and } \varphi(u_1,u_2) \neq 0,\] letting {{c1::\(e_1 := u_1\) and \(e_2 := u_2 / \varphi(u_1, u_2)\)}}, we get a hyperbolic basis of \(E\).

If \(\mathscr{B} = (e_1 , e_2)\) is a hyperbolic basis of \(E\), the lines \(\text{Span}(e_1)\) and \(\text{Span}(e_2)\) are totally isotropic, but they are non-orthogonal!

Moreover, the matrix of \(q\) in the basis \(\mathscr{B}\) is {{c1::\[\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(q)=\begin{pmatrix}0 & 1\\1 & 0\end{pmatrix}\]}} and the expression of \(q\) in \(\mathscr{B}\) is {{c1::\[q(xe_1 + ye_2) = 2xy\]}} 

so that \(\text{Span}(e_1)\) and \(\text{Span}(e_2)\) are the only isotropic subspaces of \(E\). As a consequence, any non-zero isotropic vector can always be considered as the first vector of a hyperbolic basis of \(E\).
The name hyperbolic space comes from the fact that {{c1::the set \[\mathscr{H} := \{v \in E : q(v) = 1\}\] is a hyperbola}}.

If \(\mathscr{B} = (e_1 , e_2)\) is a hyperbolic basis of \(E\), the basis \(\mathscr{C} = (f_1, f_2)\) given by \(f_1 := e_1 + \frac{1}{2} e_2\) and \(f_2 := e_1 âˆ’ \frac{1}{2} e_2\) is an orthogonal basis for \(q\) and {{c1::\[\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{C}(q) = \begin{pmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1\end{pmatrix}\]}} so that {{c1::\(q(xf_1+yf_2) = x^2-y^2\)}}.

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-plane and let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). The following are equivalent:

1. \((E,q)\) is {{c1::a hyperbolic plane}},

2. \(q\) is {{c2::non-degenerate with \(\nu(q) \geq 1\)}},

3. the signature of \(q\) is {{c1::\((1,1)\)}},

4. for any basis \(\mathscr{B}\) of \(E\), {{c2::\(\det(\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(q)) < 0\)}}.

Remark 2.13. â€” In the second equivalent condition, since \(q\) is non-degenerate, we have necessarily \( u(q) \leq \dim(E)/2 = 2/2 = 1\). In particular, the condition \( u(q) \geq 1\) is equivalent to \( u(q) = 1\).

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\) plane and let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). Then exactly one of the following holds:

1. \(E\) is {{c1::anisotropic}}, i.e. {{c1::\(E\) contains no isotropic line}}, signature {{c2::\((2,0)\) or \((0,2)\)}},

2. \(E\) is {{c2::hyperbolic}} and {{c1::\(E\) contains exactly \(2\) isotropic lines}}, signature {{c1::\((1,1)\)}},

3. \(q\) has rank {{c1::\(1\)}} and \(E\) contains {{c1::exactly one}} isotropic line {{c1::\(\ker(q)\)}}, signature {{c2::\((1,0)\) or \((0,1)\)}},

4. \(q\) is {{c1::identically \(0\)}} and {{c2::all lines of \(E\) are isotropic}}, signature {{c2::\((0,0)\)}}.

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-plane and \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). Assume {{c2::\(E\) contains at least \(3\) isotropic lines}}. Then \(E\) is {{c1::totally isotropic, i.e. the form \(q\) is identically \(0\)}}.

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(n \geq 2\). Let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\) be non-degenerate and \(u \in C(q) âˆ’ \{0\}\).

1. There exist a \(\mathbb{R}\)-plane \(P \subset E\) such that {{c1::\(u \in P\) and \((P ,q|_P )\) is hyperbolic}}.

2. If \(n \geq 3\), there exist a \(\mathbb{R}\)-plane \(P \subset E\) such that {{c1::\(u \in P\) and \(\text{rank}(q|_P ) = 1\)}}.

We say that \((E,q)\) is a hyperbolic space if there exists \(\mathbb{R}\)-planes \(E_1,...,E_r \subset E\) such that

- \(E\) is the {{c1::orthogonal direct sum of \(E_1,...,E_r : E = E_1\oplus\dots \oplus E_r\)}} and for all \(1 \leq i < j \leq r\), {{c1::\(\varphi(u, v) = 0\)}} for all \((u, v) \in E_i \times E_j\),

- for any \(1 \leq i \leq r\), {{c1::\((E_i ,q|_{E_i} )\) is a hyperbolic plane}}.

We say \(q\) is a {{c1::hyperbolic form}} on E.
If \(E\) is a hyperbolic space, its dimension is {{c1::even}}, since {{c1::\(\dim E = \dim E_1+ \dots + \dim E_r = 2r\)}}.

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(n = 2p\) and let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). The following assertions are equivalent

2. \(q\) is {{c1::non-degenerate}} with \(\nu(q) =\) {{c2::\(p = n/2\)}},

3. the signature of \(q\) is {{c1::\((p,p)\)}}.

Let \(E\) be a \(\mathbb{R}\)-vector space of dimension \(n \geq 2\) and let \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\). Then \(E\) decomposes as an orthogonal sum {{c1::\[E = \text{rad}(E)\oplus H \oplus F,\]}} where {{c2::\((H, q|_H)\)}} is {{c1::a hyperbolic space}} and {{c2::\((F, q|_F)\)}} is {{c1::anisotropic}}.

A bilinear form on \(E\) is a function \(\varphi:E \times E \to \mathbb{K}\) such that for all \(u, u', v, v' \in E\) and all \(\lambda \in \mathbb{K}\),

{{c1::\(\varphi(u+u',v) = \varphi(u,v) + \varphi(u',v)\)

\(\varphi(u,v+v') = \varphi(u,v) + \varphi(u,v')\)

\(\varphi(\lambda u, v) = \lambda \varphi(u,v) = \varphi(u, \lambda v) \)}}

A bilinear form \(\varphi\) on \(E\) is

- symmetric if {{c1::for all \(u, v \in E\), \(\varphi(u,v) = \varphi(v,u)\)}},

- definite if {{c1::for all \(u \in E -  \{0\}\), \(\varphi(u,u) \neq 0\)}},

- positive if {{c1::for all \(u \in E\), \(\varphi(u,u) \geq 0\) (when \(\mathbb{K} = \mathbb{R}\))}}.

A function \(q : E \to \mathbb{K}\) is a quadratic form on \(E\) if {{c1::

- for all \((\lambda, u) \in \mathbb{K} \times E\), \(q(\lambda u) = \lambda^2q(u)\)

- the function \(\varphi_q : E \times E \to \mathbb{K}\) defined by \[\varphi_q(u, v) := \frac{1}{2} (q(u + v) âˆ’ q(u) âˆ’ q(v))\] is bilinear symmetric.}}

Given \(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\) and given \(u, v \in E\), we have
1. (Polarization identity): {{c1::\(\varphi_q(u, v) = \frac{1}{4} (q(u + v) âˆ’ q(u âˆ’ v))\)}},
2. (Parallelogram law): {{c1::\(q(u + v) + q(u âˆ’ v) = 2(q(u) + q(v))\)}}.

The matrix of \(\varphi\) (or of \(q\)) in the basis \(\mathscr{B} = (e_1,...,e_n)\) is the \(n \times n\) matrix \(\mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B}}(\varphi) = \mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B}}(q)\) whose entries are {{c1::the coefficients \(\varphi(e_i,e_j)\) of \(\varphi\) in the basis \(\mathscr{B}\) }}.

If \(u = \sum_{i=1}^n u_i e_i\), let 
\[ \mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B} }(u) := \begin{pmatrix} u_1 \\ \vdots \\ u_n \end{pmatrix}\] Then

\(\varphi(u,v) =\) {{c1::\({}^\top \mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B} }(u) \mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B} }(\varphi) \mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B} }(v) \)}}
For any quadratic form \(q\) on \(E\), we have \(\mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{C} }(q) =\) {{c1::\({}^{\top}P^{\mathscr{C} }_{\mathscr{B} } \mathscr{M}_{\mathscr{B} }(q) P^{\mathscr{C} }_{\mathscr{B} }\)}}.

Let \(\varphi\) and \(q\). For any \((u, v) \in E \times E,\) {{c1::\[\varphi(u,v)^2 \leq q(u)q(v)\]}} Moreover, if \(\varphi\) is definite, {{c1::\(\varphi(u,v)^2 = q(u)q(v)\) iff \(u\) and \(v\) are linearly dependent}}.
Let \(\varphi\) and \(q\). For any \((u, v) \in E \times E\), {{c1::\[\sqrt{q(u+v)} \leq \sqrt{q(u)} + \sqrt{q(v)}\]}}

To the bilinear symmetric form \(\varphi_q\) one associates a linear map \(\mathscr{J}_\varphi : E \to E^\star\) given by {{c1::\[\begin{align}\mathscr{J}_{\varphi}:E &\to E^\star \\ u &\mapsto j_u \end{align}\]}} where {{c1::\(j_u(v):=\varphi(u,v)\) for all \(v \in E\)}}.
\(\ker(\varphi)\) is a vector subspace of \(E\) and \(\ker(\varphi)\) = {{c1::\[\{u \in E : \varphi(u,v)=0, \text{ for all } v \in E\}\]}}
We say \(q\) is non-degenerate if {{c1::\(\text{rank}(q) = \dim E\)}} or {{c2::\(\mathscr{J}_{\varphi}\) is an isomorphism}}. Otherwise, \(q\) is degenerate.

1. \(q\) is degenerate iff there exists {{c1::\(u \in E - \{0\}\)}} such that {{c2::\(\varphi_q(u, v) = 0\) for all \(v \in E\) (or \(j_u \equiv 0\))}}.

2. If \(q\) is {{c1::definite}}, then \(q\) is {{c2::non-degenerate}}.

3. If \(\dim E > 1\), there exists {{c1::\(q \in \mathscr{Q}(E)\) which is non-degenerate and non-definite}}.

Let \(\varphi\) and \(\mathscr{B}\). The following assertions are equivalent:

1. {{c1::\(\varphi\) is non-degenerate}}
2. {{c2::\(\text{rank}(\varphi) = \dim E\)}}
3. {{c3::\(\mathscr{J}_\varphi\) is injective}}
4. {{c3::\(\mathscr{J}_\varphi\) is surjective}}
5. {{c2::\(\ker(\varphi) = \{0\}\)}}
6. {{c4::\(\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(\varphi)\) is invertible}}

Two matrices \(A, B \in \mathscr{M}_n(\mathbb{K})\) are congruent if {{c1::there exists \(P \in \text{GL}_n(\mathbb{K})\)}} such that {{c1::\(B = {}^\top PAP\)}}.

- If \(A\) and \(B\) are congruent, then {{c1::\(\text{rank}(A) = \text{rank}(B)\)}}.

- If \(\mathbb{K} = \mathbb{R}\), \(A\) and \(B\) are congruent, then {{c1::\(\det(A)\) and \(\det(B)\) have the same sign}}.

- \(A\) and \(B\) are congruent does not {{c1::imply \(A\) and \(B\) are conjugate (similar)}}.
Two quadratic forms \(q, q'\) on \(E\) are equivalent if {{c1::there exists \(h \in \text{GL}(E)\) such that \(q=q'\circ h\)}}.

Take any base \(\mathscr{B}\) of \(E\) and let \(q, q'\) be two quadratic forms on \(E\). Then {{c1::\(q\) and \(q'\) are equivalent}} if and only if {{c2::\(\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(q)\) and \(\mathscr{M}_\mathscr{B}(q')\) are congruent}}.

\(\sim\) is an equivalence relation if it is
{{c1::- reflexive (\(A \sim A\) for all \(A\))
- symmetric (\(A \sim B\) implies \(B \sim A\) for all \(A, B\))
- transitive (\(A \sim B\) and \(B \sim C\) implies \(A \sim C\) for all \(A, B, C\))}}
